abstract.para: Linux Doesn't Have to Be Hard: A Beginner's Guide will gently and humorously introduce you to the Linux operating system. It comprehensively covers controlling the computer using the keyboard, rather than the mouse, working with files, directories or text, as well as automating common tasks. The book is intended for novice Linux systems administrators or ordinary Linux users that want to learn more about their operating system.
To make the most out of this book, you are advised to read it next to a Linux machine, so that you can immediately practice what you learn.

The contents of the book include:
working with files and directories combining commands using pipes transforming text using filtering commands searching text for sophisticated patterns using powerful regular expressions saving time when typing commands by using helpful features of the bash command-line implementation editing text using vi, a powerful editor for Linux gurus automating repetitive tasks using shell scripting managing users on a Linux system managing file security accessing and searching Linux manuals legal aspects of Linux, especially copyright licensing a guide to Linux distributions a brief history of Linux
The book does not describe graphical end-user applications, such as web browsers, video players or office suites, because they are not fundamental features of the operating system.

This book belongs to the Userbie series of guides, which are available gratis. They are community-developed and you are encouraged to contribute. Click on the [feedback] link, located at the end of every paragraph, to provide feedback to the maintainers. If your suggested changes are incorporated into the guide, your name will feature as a contributor to the guide.
